10:00 - 12:00, room S4

*Seminar: Modern Methods of Data Mining*.
10:00 a.m. - 12:00 p.m., room L9

*Seminar: Modern Databases*
8:00 - 10:00 am, room

--------------------------------------------------

*** Tuesday, May 21, 2024 ***.
*Algebraic Seminar*.
10:00 - 12:00, room S5

*Seminar of the Department of Ergodic Theory and Dynamical Systems*.
10:00 a.m. - 12:00 p.m., room SS2
*Abdul Gaffar Khan*.
*Bi-asymptotic c-Expansivity and decomposition theorems*.
In this talk, we will define bi-asymptotically c-expansivity for continuous surjective maps on metric spaces and study its relationship with other variants of expansivity. We also provide an example to establish that expansive homeomorphisms need not be bi-asymptotically expansive. Finally we prove decomposition theorems for bi-asymptotically c-expansive continuous surjective maps with the shadowing property on compact metric spaces. This talk is based on the joint-work with Tarun Das and Rohit Nageshwar.

*Seminar by the Department of Nonlinear Mathematical Analysis*.
10:15 am - 11:45 am, room S3
*Adam Konysz (WMiI, UMK)*.
*Semiclassical states for the curl-curl operator equation*.

*Seminar on Computer Science*.
12:00 - 14:00, room L9
*Jerzy Białkowski*.
*Algorithmic approach to selected problems in representation theory of algebras*.
In the paper I would like to present a proposed approach to problems from the
representation theory of algebras consisting in "translation" of problems
formulated in the "language" of restricted quiver algebras into (solvable
effectively solvable) problems in the theory of formal languages.

In particular, I will consider how one can "choose" an alphabet, how to
define a language, how to construct a grammar and a system of term reduction.
In doing so, I will try to place particular emphasis on the choice of presentation of
of data allowing to maintain an acceptable level of complexity
time and memory complexity.

The paper is intended mainly for those who have previously dealt with the
dealing with the theory of formal languages (who have learned it to a degree of
at least basic level), but who have not necessarily encountered before
with the theory of representations of algebras.Thus, the issues of the theory of
representations of algebras will be reduced to small "slices" for
which, on the one hand, it will not take too long to give the necessary definitions
much time, and which, on the other hand, will be necessary from the point of view of the
the paper.

The paper will largely take the form of a case study.
More on the theoretical basis (from the representation theory of algebras)
and details of the algorithmic part (by design, the paper is to
be 1-part, so in this form it will not be possible to
devote too much time to them) can be found in the article

Jerzy Białkowski, An algorithm for the periodicity of deformed
preprojective algebras of Dynkin types E6, E7 and E8, Applied
Mathematics and Computation, Vol. 409, 126289, 2021.
(DOI:10.1016/j.jpaa.2021.106886, arXiv:2006.15405)

*Seminar on Computer Science: Formal Languages and Concurrency*.
12:00 - 14:00, room L9

*Seminar of the Department of Differential Equations*.
12:00 - 14:00, room SS2
*Christian Pötzsche (Universität Klagenfurt - Austria)*.
*Nonautonomous Bifurcations in Carathéodory Differential Equations*.
The classical bifurcation theory of (autonomous) dynamical systems does not apply to differential equations depending explicitly on time because constant solutions typically do not exist and eigenvalues do not indicate stability. Based on bounded entire solutions and the dichotomy (Sacker-Sell) spectrum, as appropriate extensions, we survey a corresponding local nonautonomous bifurcation theory, which, for instance, applies to differential equations allowing only measurable time dependence.
